items.title: tasks.find_by_project: Obtain custom fields's VALUE as part of opt_fields
items.body:
`client.tasks.find_by_project(gid, opt_fields='custom_fields.name, custom_fields.value')`

Expected:
```json
"custom_fields": [
      {
        "gid": "4907421210123456",
        "name": "Estimated hours",
        "value": "6"
      }
]
```

Actual:
```json
"custom_fields": [
      {
        "gid": "4907421210123456",
        "name": "Estimated hours"
      }
]
```


What's the way to obtain the actual **values** from tasks custom fields (in the context of multi-tasks API calls)?

items.title: Getting memberships through get_task with opt_fields does not work
items.body:
Hi - I am trying something like this:

`print(client.tasks.get_task('1177562507257193', {
      'opt_fields': "memberships, custom_fields, tags"}))`

I get custom_fields and tags but memberships show up as an empty dictionary inside of an empty list. If I do not use opt_fields, I get values under memberships which shows me the projects and sections the specific task is in.

items.title: Completed_since syntax questions
items.body:
I'm having difficulty figuring out the syntax to search for completed items from the client.tasks.search_in_workspace. the documentation says that completed_since=now will return only completed answers, but when tried it, it didn't work. How exactly it is written? I tried something like

`client.tasks.search_in_workspace([workspace id], params={'text': {'job', 'completed_since=now'}})

What is the proper syntax for getting completed tasks? Thanks

items.title: Iterating through portfolios using Python
items.body:
Working with portfolios and I would like to do two things:
1. Pull only the portfolios associated with my "team" (find_by_team) and
2. Figure out how to iterate through the portfolios once I have them.

As a test, I can do the following:
```
ports = self.client.portfolios.find_all()
```
Something is returned in `ports` but none of the typical iteration techniques work, e.g.
```
1. for item in ports:
2. option_lst = list(ports)
 for p in enumerate(option_lst):
3. for p in ports.items
```

I obviously do not understand the iterators in this API since, according to the very few examples provided, I can iterate through `projects` using option #2 but when iterating through `tasks` I must use option #1.  Since none of the above work for portfolios and I can't find code examples, can someone help by answering the two questions above?  Thanks!

items.title: Accessing images associated with tasks via the Python API
items.body: I would like to access the images associated with tasks using the API but it does not appear to be documented.  Given you are providing the user's profile image (which is way less important than the images associated with project tasks), I am hoping there is way to also access task images.  Thx

items.title: Is it possible to refresh access token automatically?
items.body:
I see that to create asana session there are 2 options:
**asana.Client.access_token(access_token)** and **asana.Client.oauth(kwargs)**

If I use **asana.Client.access_token("...")** sometimes I get **TokenExpiredError: (token_expired)**. 

I don't wan't to refresh token mannually every time when I need to interact with Asana, so I tried to use **asana.Client.oauth(...)** with **auto_refresh_url** and **auto_refresh_kwargs**, but in this case I've got "**NoAuthorizationError**: No Authorization: The bearer token has expired...."

Can I handle automatic token refresh to avoid TokenExpiredError?

items.title: ASANA_ACCESS_TOKEN - asana.error.NoAuthorizationError: No Authorization: Not Authorized
items.body:
I rewrote the Dockerfile to

```
FROM python:3

WORKDIR /usr/app

ADD requirements.txt /usr/app/requirements.txt

RUN pip install -r requirements.txt

ADD asana /usr/app/asana
ADD examples /usr/app/examples
ADD tests /usr/app/tests
ADD setup.py /usr/app/setup.py

RUN find . -name '*.pyc' -delete

RUN python --version

RUN python setup.py install
```

created an .env file with

```
ASANA_CLIENT_ID=<copied client id from asana>
ASANA_CLIENT_SECRET=<copied client secret from asana>
ASANA_ACCESS_TOKEN=<copied access token from asana>
```

Then I builded the image

```
$ docker build --tag asana .  
```

Started the container

`docker run --env-file .env --name asana-docker -it asana bash `

navigated to the examples folder and tried to start the script `example-create-task.py`

But it failed to access

then I did

```
root@<docker-id>:/usr/app/examples# python
Python 3.8.1 (default, Jan  3 2020, 22:44:00) 
[GCC 8.3.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import os
>>> import asana
>>> asana.__version__
'0.9.2'
>>> client.users.me()['name']
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/asana-0.9.2-py3.8.egg/asana/resources/gen/users.py", line 21, in me
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/asana-0.9.2-py3.8.egg/asana/client.py", line 171, in get
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/asana-0.9.2-py3.8.egg/asana/client.py", line 89, in request
asana.error.NoAuthorizationError: No Authorization: Not Authorized
```

items.title: Relax dependency on requests-oauthlib
items.body:
In your [requirements.txt](https://github.com/Asana/python-asana/blob/master/requirements.txt#L2) you depend on `requests_oauthlib>=0.8.0<2.0`, but in your [setup.py](https://github.com/Asana/python-asana/blob/master/setup.py#L30), it says:
```
install_requires=[
        'requests >= 2.20.0, == 2.*',
        'requests_oauthlib >= 0.8.0, == 0.8.*',
        'six >= 1.10, == 1.*'
    ],
```
Why is there a difference between the two? This is forcing our project to use `0.8.0`, which makes using this library impossible, because another dependency requires `requests-oauthlib>=1.0.0`.

items.title: Small typo "it's" vs "its"
items.body:
Hello, I think there's a minor typo in README.md.

Incorrect:
Collections (methods returning an array as **it's** 'data' property):

Correct:
Collections (methods returning an array as **its** 'data' property):

Thank you for fixing it in advance!

items.title: Raise StopIteration causes breakage in Python 3.7
items.body:
In Python 3.7, due to PEP 479, StopIteration errors raised inside generator functions are converted to RuntimeErrors.  (Not talking about StopIteration inside dunder-next methods, just inside functions that use yield.)

The `PageIterator.items` method raises just such a StopIteration error when it's through, and now in 3.7 when I try to iterate over pages of items I get a RuntimeError at the end.

Here's the line that causes the RuntimeError.
https://github.com/Asana/python-asana/blob/14130bc76c48fb998a3c95daef1c1892e8751458/asana/page_iterator.py#L61

Apparently, according to PEP 479, this idiom of "raise a StopIteration error to signal when the generator function finished" was never really necessary, just permissible.  But it caused subtle bugs and now it's actively considered harmful.

According to the PEP, the fix in this case is to simply let the function return, a/k/a just remove that line.  The PEP claims this is fully compatible with previous versions of Python.

I'm not really set up to test that change, but I hope it's as easy as the PEP makes it sound?

items.title: me = client.users.me() causing error
items.body:
Hi! I am for some reason not able to get the example to return a result?
I am entering this code into a program and the repl:
```python
import asana
import os

# Authentication module containing Auth Variables
try:
    import auth
except:
    pass

client = asana.Client(os.getenv('INTERCOM_API_TOKEN', '123'))
me = client.users.me()
```

and this is the error I am getting:

```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-3-188709321cc0> in <module>()
      9
     10 client = asana.Client(os.getenv('INTERCOM_API_TOKEN','Authentication 123'))
---> 11 me = client.users.me()

~/GitHub/cuban-pete-1995/python/lib/python3.6/site-packages/asana/resources/gen/users.py in me(self, params, **options)
     19         [params] : {Object} Parameters for the request
     20         """
---> 21         return self.client.get("/users/me", params, **options)
     22
     23     def find_by_id(self, user, params={}, **options):

~/GitHub/cuban-pete-1995/python/lib/python3.6/site-packages/asana/client.py in get(self, path, query, **options)
    114         # options in the query takes precendence
    115         query = _merge(query_options, api_options, parameter_options, query)
--> 116         return self.request('get', path, params=query, **options)
    117
    118     def get_collection(self, path, query, **options):

~/GitHub/cuban-pete-1995/python/lib/python3.6/site-packages/asana/client.py in request(self, method, path, **options)
     80         while True:
     81             try:
---> 82                 response = getattr(self.session, method)(
     83                     url, auth=self.auth, **request_options)
     84                 if response.status_code in STATUS_MAP:

AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'get'
```

Looking at the error it looks like it is specifying a 'get' variable but the request function is not handling it very well potentially it Is there something I am doing wrong?

items.title: Tag and release v0.8.0
items.body: The project was bumped to version 0.8.0 but this version was not tagged and released so cannot be specified by dependant projects wanting to take advantage of updated API.

items.title: completed_since question
items.body:
I have a section on a board which has 3 tasks, 2 of which are complete. i ran this code below, thinking it would only return the item which is not complete, however it returned all 3 items. do you have a suggestion as to why this would be?

```
sections = list(client.sections.find_by_project(board_id))
need_qa_approval_section = next(x for x in sections if x['name'] == 'Need QA Approval')

params = {
    'completed_since': '2099-01-01',
    'section': need_qa_approval_section['id']
}
tasks = client.tasks.find_all(params)

for task in tasks:
    print task
```

items.title: OpenSSL update issue
items.body:
If you encounter problem while trying to update your OpenSSL version, like :

```
$ brew link --force openssl
Warning: Refusing to link: openssl
Linking keg-only openssl means you may end up linking against the insecure,
deprecated system OpenSSL while using the headers from Homebrew's openssl.
Instead, pass the full include/library paths to your compiler e.g.:
  -I/usr/local/opt/openssl/include -L/usr/local/opt/openssl/lib
```

have a look at this link : https://medium.com/@katopz/how-to-upgrade-openssl-8d005554401 - might help :)

items.body: Is there anyway to get description from the task? I cannot seem to find any option reading the code

items.title: Too restrictive requirements
items.body:
We use `asana==0.6.5` and want to upgrade requests to the latest version `requests==2.18.4`.
However, in `setup.py` you require `requests==2.14`:

https://github.com/Asana/python-asana/blob/7475f9419619da628b7122271e36a13196068ecb/setup.py#L29

Will asana client break with `requests==2.18`? If not, please make requirements less restrictive.
Something like `>=2.14.2, <3.0a0`.

items.title: error in install_requires
items.body:
Clean git checkout, execute python setup.py bdist_rpm

python --version: Python 2.7.5

> error in asana setup command: 'install_requires' must be a string or list of strings containing valid project/version requirement specifiers

I also receive this message when I try to pip install the package.

If I remove the parts after the first comma, the rpm builds:

```
diff --git a/setup.py b/setup.py
index 6adedd7..a1d2ce3 100755
--- a/setup.py
+++ b/setup.py
@@ -26,9 +26,9 @@ setup(
         'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.4'
     ],
     install_requires=[
-        'requests >=2.14.2, == 2.14.*',
-        'requests_oauthlib >= 0.6.1, == 0.6.*',
-        'six >= 1.10.0, == 1.10.*'
+        'requests >=2.14.2',
+        'requests_oauthlib >= 0.6.1',
+        'six >= 1.10.0'
     ],
     author='Asana, Inc',
     # author_email='',
```

┆Issue is synchronized with this [Asana task](https://app.asana.com/0/182692189208479/398848713596197)

items.title: Fix versioning for setup.py
items.body:
Right now it throws an import error when trying to import from the version file because the import doesn't make sense anymore. Additionally, you can't actually import that `version.py` now because ultimately 3rd party dependencies are imported along the way, and it'll break on installation for those without those dependencies already installed.

Going to add a fix to read this in regex style, similar to other libraries and referenced in the python packaging guide.

0.5.1 was added manually, but it'd be great to add a wheel along with the sdist when cutting a new version.

items.title: Add supported versions of python
items.body: In `setup.py` it asserts it supports Python 2.6+, but does that include Python 3? Should make it explicit for PyPI in the classifiers.

items.title: Add LICENSE
items.body: It's currently empty...

items.title: Update requests_oauthlib from 0.5.0 -> 0.6.1
items.body:
There are a few bug fixes, including issue https://github.com/requests/requests-oauthlib/issues/211 which breaks the authorization workflow using the python API.

Will still need to make new distributions on PyPI in order for pip to pull these down.

items.title: Attribute Error with Python 2.6
items.body:
I use your API at my workplace and, for enterprise reasons, use Python 2.6. Unfortunately using your library fails with that version of Python because of line 14 in asana.client, i.e.:

`if sys.version_info.major == 3:`

The "major" attribute was introduced in 2.7, so I'd appreciate it if you could find a different way to express this, some suggestions:
- The "forgiveness" approach:

```
try:
    import urllib.parse as urlparse
except ImportError:
    import urllib as urlparse
```
- The "permission" approach:

```
if hasattr(sys.version_info, 'major') and sys.version_info.major == 3:
    import urllib.parse as urlparse
else:
    import urllib as urlparse
```

Anyway thanks for building this API, hopefully you update this issue because I don't really like overwriting client libraries.

Tim

items.title: auth with Personal Access Token for CLI scripts
items.body:
A valid PAT, verified with the suggested:

```
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer ACCESS_TOKEN" https://app.asana.com/api/1.0/users/me
```

an present as an environment variable `ASANA_ACCESS_TOKEN="..."`, used as:

```
client = asana.Client.access_token(os.environ['ASANA_ACCESS_TOKEN'])
```

raises an exception when the library attempts to use Oauth2 to create a session

```
$ python example-create-task.py 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "example-create-task.py", line 29, in <module>
    client = asana.Client.access_token(os.environ['ASANA_ACCESS_TOKEN'])
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/asana/client.py", line 224, in access_token
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/asana/session.py", line 11, in __init__
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/requests_oauthlib/oauth2_session.py", line 65, in __init__
    self.client_id = client_id or client.client_id
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'client_id'
```

items.title: External string IDs are not supported on task objects
items.body:
tasks.find_by_id() only takes a numeric ID and therefore does not support string external IDs. Consider supporting string IDs or a separate method to look up external IDs.

https://github.com/Asana/python-asana/blob/master/asana/resources/gen/tasks.py#L53
